articles.headline: Governors Say Trump’s Order on Pandemic Relief Could Wreck State Budgets
articles.snippet: With Congress at an impasse on stimulus talks, disarray over resuming negotiations bodes poorly for reaching a deal this week.
articles.abstract: With Congress at an impasse on stimulus talks, disarray over resuming negotiations bodes poorly for reaching a deal this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Governors across the United States struggled on Monday with how to make good on President Trump’s order that their economically battered states deliver billions more in unemployment benefits to jobless residents.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater, Emily Cochrane, Sarah Mervosh and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: SoftBank Claws Back Into the Black After Historic Losses
articles.snippet: Asset sales and a hot stock market have helped fuel a rebound for the beleaguered Japanese conglomerate, which runs the world’s largest tech fund.
articles.abstract: Asset sales and a hot stock market have helped fuel a rebound for the beleaguered Japanese conglomerate, which runs the world’s largest tech fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Just four months ago, Masayoshi Son, the daring billionaire who leads the Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, looked as if he might lose it all.

articles.headline: A Bible Burning, a Russian News Agency and a Story Too Good to Check Out
articles.snippet: A story about protesters burning Bibles drew condemnation from conservatives. It now appears to have been wildly exaggerated — and the first viral hit in Russia’s 2020 disinformation campaign.
articles.abstract: A story about protesters burning Bibles drew condemnation from conservatives. It now appears to have been wildly exaggerated — and the first viral hit in Russia’s 2020 disinformation campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For some of President Trump’s loudest cheerleaders, it was a story too good to check out: Black Lives Matters protesters in Portland, Ore., had burned a stack of Bibles, and then topped off the fire with American flags. There was even a video to prove it.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Are Racial Attitudes Really Changing? Some Black Activists Are Skeptical
articles.snippet: For community activists on the South Side of Chicago, words are insufficient, and an embrace of the Black Lives Matter movement requires caring for communities that both Democrats and Republicans have ignored.
articles.abstract: For community activists on the South Side of Chicago, words are insufficient, and an embrace of the Black Lives Matter movement requires caring for communities that both Democrats and Republicans have ignored.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The old guard of this city’s Roseland neighborhood, a community on the South Side famous for molding a young Barack Obama and infamous for its current blight, has never forgotten the fruit trees.

articles.headline: Coronavirus Tests the Leadership Style of Goldman Sachs’s C.E.O.
articles.snippet: The pandemic has given David Solomon a chance to try out a more open-minded approach in tune with the bank’s young work force.
articles.abstract: The pandemic has given David Solomon a chance to try out a more open-minded approach in tune with the bank’s young work force.
articles.lead_paragraph: David M. Solomon started 2020 on his back foot.
